MUCH better with the SurtPrefixScope.  RHEL box is averaging 40pps 
and the SUSE on 60pps after 3 hours.  I'll let them run and then try 
another set of 75k seeds.  It will be interesting to see if the 
newer kernel really makes that big of a difference or if it's just a 
fluke.

Thanks,
Greg


> The original options (PathScope, HostScope, and the default 
DomainScope)
> all do an iteration through the entire seed-list-derived list of
> acceptable URL-patterns to decide if a newly-discovered URL can be
> ruled in. With a 75K seed list, that inefficiency really hurts, and
> the stack dump may show most of your threads in *Scope checking.
> 
> The newer, non-default SurtPrefixScope can more-or-less simulate 
all
> those original scopes, much more efficiently. A binary search 
through a
> sorted list of acceptable 'surt' prefixes rules URLs in or out with
> far fewer comparisons.
>
